dn2:0.2.eng: The Fruits of the Ascetic Life

dn2:1.0.eng: 1. A Discussion With the King’s Ministers

dn2:1.1.comm: This sutta with its commentary was translated by Bhikkhu Bodhi in his The Fruits of Recluseship.

dn2:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavane mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi.
dn2:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha in the Mango Grove of Jīvaka Komārabhacca, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.
dn2:1.2.comm: This monastery belonged to the Buddha’s doctor, Jīvaka, who appears later in the sutta. His story is told in Kd 8, where we learn that he was raised by Prince Abhaya of Magadha, a Jain (MN 58) who was also interested in the teachings of Pūraṇa Kassapa (SN 46.56). MN 55 on eating meat is addressed to him.

dn2:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tadahuposathe pannarase komudiyā cātumāsiniyā puṇṇāya puṇṇamāya rattiyā rājāmaccaparivuto uparipāsādavaragato nisinno hoti.
dn2:1.3.eng: Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the Komudī full moon on the fifteenth day of the fourth month—and King Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, was sitting upstairs in the royal longhouse surrounded by his ministers.
dn2:1.3.comm: The Komudī was an especially celebrated full moon on the last month of the rainy season (kattikā, October/November), when the skies were clear, the lotuses (kumudā) were in bloom, and the moon was in conjunction with the Pleiades, which gave the month its name.

dn2:1.4.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tadahuposathe udānaṃ udānesi:
dn2:1.4.eng: Then Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, expressed this heartfelt sentiment,
dn2:1.4.comm: Ajātasattu (“one against whom no foe is born”) was the son of Bimbisāra and heir to the Haryaṅka dynasty of Magadha. In inscription and Jain tradition he is also called Kūṇika. Jain tradition holds that his mother was Cellaṇā daughter of Ceṭaka, a Licchavī ruler from Vesālī. This begs the question as to why Cellaṇā was said to be “of Videha”; perhaps he married a Videhan princess to forge an alliance with the Licchavī’s northern neighbors. In any case, this is more plausible than the Buddhist tradition that his mother was Kosalan.

dn2:1.5.pli: “ramaṇīyā vata bho dosinā ratti, abhirūpā vata bho dosinā ratti, dassanīyā vata bho dosinā ratti, pāsādikā vata bho dosinā ratti, lakkhaññā vata bho dosinā ratti.
dn2:1.5.eng: “Oh, sirs, this moonlit night is so very delightful, so beautiful, so glorious, so lovely, so striking.
dn2:1.5.comm: Pāsādikā here does not mean “tranquil”; it is part of a stock list of terms meaning “beautiful, attractive” (eg. DN 4:13.7). | Lakkhaññā is unique in early Pali. It is probably a synonym in the sense of “possessing remarkable features, striking”, rather than “auspicious”.

dn2:1.6.pli: Kaṃ nu khvajja samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā payirupāseyyāma, yaṃ no payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā”ti?
dn2:1.6.eng: Now, what ascetic or brahmin might I pay homage to today, paying homage to whom my mind might find peace?”
dn2:1.6.comm: The king seeks redemption through his own actions; it is not that the ascetic has any special power to bring peace to his mind. | The sutta is deliberately holding back the reason for the king’s distress. Compare AN 5.50, where the reason for King Muṇḍa seeking solace is stated up front.

dn2:2.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aññataro rājāmacco rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ etadavoca:
dn2:2.1.eng: When he had spoken, one of the king’s ministers said to him,
dn2:2.1.comm: Though the king mentioned “ascetics and brahmins”, his advisers only recommend famous teachers of the ascetics (samaṇa). For a shorter survey of their doctrines, see SN 2.30.

dn2:2.2.pli: “ayaṃ, deva, pūraṇo kassapo saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
dn2:2.2.eng: “Sire, Pūraṇa Kassapa leads an order and a community, and tutors a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
dn2:2.2.comm: A little-known teacher of the inefficacy of action and consequence, Pūraṇa was poorly regarded even by his own students (MN 77:6.19). He is said to have advocated a doctrine of six classes of rebirth (AN 6.57. The same text reverentially mentions Makkhali Gosāla, and it seems Pūraṇa, like Gosāla and Pakudha, was a defining teacher of the Ājīvakas. | Pūraṇa means “filling” (not purāṇa, “ancient”).

dn2:2.3.eng: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.

dn2:2.4.pli: Appeva nāma devassa pūraṇaṃ kassapaṃ payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā”ti.
dn2:2.4.eng: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”

dn2:2.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
dn2:2.5.eng: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.
dn2:2.5.comm: The reason for the king’s silence is revealed later. The narrative is full of foreshadowing.

dn2:3.1.pli: Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ etadavoca:
dn2:3.1.eng: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,

dn2:3.2.pli: “ayaṃ, deva, makkhali gosālo saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
dn2:3.2.eng: “Sire, the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla leads an order and a community, and tutors a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
dn2:3.2.comm: Founder of the Ājīvakas, who became the third largest ascetic movement after Buddhism and Jainism. None of their texts survive, but their teachings can be partially reconstructed from Buddhist and Jain sources. He practiced with Mahāvīra for six years before an acrimonious split, following which he developed his doctrine of hard determinism. Makkhali denotes a kind of ascetic bearing a bamboo staff, so (like the similar appellations nigaṇṭha and samaṇa) it indicates his affiliation. This being so, and noting that Buddhist Sanskrit texts spell his name as gośālīputra etc., the second name (like nātaputta and gotama) might indicate his clan. However, I can find no trace of such a clan, and both Jain and Buddhist tradition, albeit unreliably, say the name arose because he was born in a cowshed.

dn2:3.3.eng: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.

dn2:3.4.pli: Appeva nāma devassa makkhaliṃ gosālaṃ payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā”ti.
dn2:3.4.eng: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”

dn2:3.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
dn2:3.5.eng: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.

dn2:4.1.pli: Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ etadavoca:
dn2:4.1.eng: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,

dn2:4.2.pli: “ayaṃ, deva, ajito kesakambalo saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
dn2:4.2.eng: “Sire, Ajita of the hair blanket leads an order and a community, and tutors a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
dn2:4.2.comm: A materialist, he was an early proponent of the ideas later known as Cārvāka. Kesakambala means “hair-blanket”, which was worn as an ascetic practice (AN 3.137).

dn2:4.3.eng: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.

dn2:4.4.pli: Appeva nāma devassa ajitaṃ kesakambalaṃ payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā”ti.
dn2:4.4.eng: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”

dn2:4.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
dn2:4.5.eng: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.

dn2:5.1.pli: Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ etadavoca:
dn2:5.1.eng: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,

dn2:5.2.pli: “ayaṃ, deva, pakudho kaccāyano saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
dn2:5.2.eng: “Sire, Pakudha Kaccāyana leads an order and a community, and tutors a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
dn2:5.2.comm: Another obscure teacher, he taught a reductive atomism which negated the possibility of action with consequences. His first name is sometimes spelled Kakudha; both words signify a hump or crest. He was likely one of the early teachers of the Ājīvakas.

dn2:5.3.eng: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.

dn2:5.4.pli: Appeva nāma devassa pakudhaṃ kaccāyanaṃ payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā”ti.
dn2:5.4.eng: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”

dn2:5.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
dn2:5.5.eng: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.

dn2:6.1.pli: Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ etadavoca:
dn2:6.1.eng: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,

dn2:6.2.pli: “ayaṃ, deva, sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
dn2:6.2.eng: “Sire, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta leads an order and a community, and tutors a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
dn2:6.2.comm: An agnostic, he is evidently the “wanderer Sañjaya” who was the first teacher of Sāriputta and Moggallāna before they left him to follow the Buddha (Kd 1:23.1.1). His name is obscure. Sanskrit spells it vairaṭṭīputra, with several variations, but always with ṭi. The commentary says he was the “son of Belaṭṭha”; a Belaṭṭha Kaccāna is found selling sugar at Kd 1:26.1.2, supporting the idea that Belaṭṭha was a personal rather than clan name.

dn2:6.3.eng: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.

dn2:6.4.pli: Appeva nāma devassa sañcayaṃ belaṭṭhaputtaṃ payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā”ti.
dn2:6.4.eng: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”

dn2:6.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
dn2:6.5.eng: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.

dn2:7.1.pli: Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṃ māgadhaṃ ajātasattuṃ vedehiputtaṃ etadavoca:
dn2:7.1.eng: Another of the king’s ministers said to him,

dn2:7.2.pli: “ayaṃ, deva, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
dn2:7.2.eng: “Sire, the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan leads an order and a community, and tutors a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people. He is of long standing, long gone forth; he is advanced in years and has reached the final stage of life.
dn2:7.2.comm: The Jain leader Mahāvīra Vardhamāna is known as Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta in Pali texts. He is regarded as the 24th supreme leader of the Jains, although only he and his predecessor Pārśvanātha (not mentioned in the Pali) are historical. Nigaṇṭha means “knotless” (i.e. without attachments). As a term for Jain ascetics it is also found in Jain literature. Nātaputta indicates his clan the Ñātikas (Sanskrit jñātiputra; Prākrit nāyaputta). The Pali tradition has confused ñāti (“family”) with nāṭa (“dancer”). Thus Nigaṇṭha Nātaputta means “the Jain monk of the Ñātika clan”. | Jainism and Buddhism are the only ancient samaṇa movements to survive to the present day. The primary Jain teaching is the practice of non-violence while burning off past kamma by fervent austerities in order to reach omniscient liberation.

dn2:7.3.eng: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.

dn2:7.4.pli: Appeva nāma devassa nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā”ti.
dn2:7.4.eng: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”

dn2:7.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
dn2:7.5.eng: But when he had spoken, the king kept silent.

dn2:8.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena jīvako komārabhacco rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa avidūre tuṇhībhūto nisinno hoti.
dn2:8.1.eng: Now at that time Jīvaka Komārabhacca was sitting silently not far from the king.
dn2:8.1.comm: His absence of speech signifies his wisdom. The narrative creates a dramatic expectation through his stillness, an exquisitely Buddhist aesthetic choice.

dn2:8.2.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca:
dn2:8.2.eng: Then the king said to him,

dn2:8.3.eng: “But my dear Jīvaka, why are you silent?”

dn2:8.4.pli: “Ayaṃ, deva, bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho amhākaṃ ambavane viharati mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṃ aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi.
dn2:8.4.eng: “Sire, the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha is staying in my mango grove together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.
dn2:8.4.comm: According to the Vinaya, a monastery is normally offered to the “Saṅgha of the four quarters” and becomes their inalienable property. In the suttas this is not so clear, and it seems that Jīvaka still regarded the property as his. In practice there would have been a variety of arrangements, as there are today.

dn2:8.5.pli: Taṃ kho pana bhagavantaṃ evaṃ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:

dn2:8.6.pli: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā’ti.
dn2:8.6.eng: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
dn2:8.6.comm: The first appearance of the famous iti pi so formula. It is still recited in praise of the Buddha in Theravada communities.

dn2:8.7.eng: Let Your Majesty pay homage to him.

dn2:8.8.pli: Appeva nāma devassa bhagavantaṃ payirupāsato cittaṃ pasīdeyyā”ti.
dn2:8.8.eng: Hopefully in so doing your mind will find peace.”

dn2:8.9.eng: “Well then, my dear Jīvaka, have the elephants readied.”

dn2:9.1.pli: “Evaṃ, devā”ti kho jīvako komārabhacco rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa paṭissuṇitvā pañcamattāni hatthinikāsatāni kappāpetvā rañño ca ārohaṇīyaṃ nāgaṃ, rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa paṭivedesi:
dn2:9.1.eng: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied Jīvaka. He had around five hundred female elephants readied, in addition to the king’s bull elephant for riding. Then he informed the king,

dn2:10.1.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto pañcasu hatthinikāsatesu paccekā itthiyo āropetvā ārohaṇīyaṃ nāgaṃ abhiruhitvā ukkāsu dhāriyamānāsu rājagahamhā niyyāsi mahaccarājānubhāvena, yena jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavanaṃ tena pāyāsi.
dn2:10.1.eng: Then King Ajātasattu had women mounted on each of the five hundred female elephants, while he mounted his bull elephant. With attendants carrying torches, he set out in full royal pomp from Rājagaha to Jīvaka’s mango grove.
dn2:10.1.comm: Indian kings were guarded by armed women inside the harem (Kauṭilya’s Arthaśāstra 1.21.1) and also while on hunt (Megasthenes’s Indica, via Strabo XV. i. 53–56). This passage may be the earliest evidence for this long-lasting practice. See also DN 23:15.4.

dn2:10.2.pli: Atha kho rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa avidūre ambavanassa ahudeva bhayaṃ, ahu chambhitattaṃ, ahu lomahaṃso.
dn2:10.2.eng: But as he drew near the mango grove, the king became frightened, scared, his hair standing on end.

dn2:10.3.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhīto saṃviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca:

dn2:10.4.eng: “My dear Jīvaka, I hope you’re not deceiving me!

dn2:10.5.pli: Kacci maṃ, samma jīvaka, na palambhesi?
dn2:10.5.eng: I hope you’re not betraying me!

dn2:10.6.pli: Kacci maṃ, samma jīvaka, na paccatthikānaṃ desi?
dn2:10.6.eng: I hope you’re not turning me over to my enemies!

dn2:10.7.pli: Kathañhi nāma tāva mahato bhikkhusaṅghassa aḍḍhateḷasānaṃ bhikkhusatānaṃ neva khipitasaddo bhavissati, na ukkāsitasaddo na nigghoso”ti.
dn2:10.7.eng: For how on earth can there be no sound of coughing or clearing throats or any noise in such a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants?”
dn2:10.7.comm: The silence of the Buddha’s assembly is often contrasted with the rowdy gatherings of other ascetics, for example that of Poṭṭhapāda at DN 9:3.1.

dn2:10.8.eng: “Do not fear, great king, do not fear!

dn2:10.11.eng: or turning you over to your enemies.

dn2:10.12.pli: Abhikkama, mahārāja, abhikkama, mahārāja, ete maṇḍalamāḷe dīpā jhāyantī”ti.
dn2:10.12.eng: Go forward, great king, go forward! Those are lamps shining in the pavilion.”
dn2:10.12.comm: This is a double pun. Dīpa means “lamp” or “island, refuge”, while jhāyati means “burning” or “meditating”. So it could be rendered, “those are saviors meditating in the pavilion”. Jhāyati is the verb form of jhāna (“absorption”), which is the central practice of meditation described below.

dn2:11.0.eng: 3. The Question About the Fruits of the Ascetic Life

dn2:11.1.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto yāvatikā nāgassa bhūmi nāgena gantvā, nāgā paccorohitvā, pattikova yena maṇḍalamāḷassa dvāraṃ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā jīvakaṃ komārabhaccaṃ etadavoca:
dn2:11.1.eng: Then King Ajātasattu rode on the elephant as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the pavilion door on foot, where he asked Jīvaka,

dn2:11.2.eng: “But my dear Jīvaka, where is the Buddha?”
dn2:11.2.comm: The Buddha looked like any other monk. But this also reveals Ajātasattu’s spiritual blindness.

dn2:11.3.eng: “That is the Buddha, great king, that is the Buddha!

dn2:11.4.pli: eso, mahārāja, bhagavā majjhimaṃ thambhaṃ nissāya puratthābhimukho nisinno purakkhato bhikkhusaṅghassā”ti.
dn2:11.4.eng: He’s sitting against the central column facing east, in front of the Saṅgha of mendicants.”

dn2:12.1.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṃ aṭṭhāsi.
dn2:12.1.eng: Then the king went up to the Buddha and stood to one side.
dn2:12.1.comm: He has not yet gained faith, so does not bow.

dn2:12.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ ṭhito kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhībhūtaṃ tuṇhībhūtaṃ bhikkhusaṅghaṃ anuviloketvā rahadamiva vippasannaṃ udānaṃ udānesi:
dn2:12.2.eng: He looked around the Saṅgha of mendicants, who were so very silent, like a still, clear lake, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment,

dn2:12.3.pli: “iminā me upasamena udayabhaddo kumāro samannāgato hotu, yenetarahi upasamena bhikkhusaṅgho samannāgato”ti.
dn2:12.3.eng: “May my son, Prince Udāyibhadda, be blessed with such peace as the Saṅgha of mendicants now enjoys!”

dn2:12.4.eng: “Has your mind gone to one you love, great king?”
dn2:12.4.comm: The Buddha, though fully aware of Ajātasattu’s crimes, responds to him with compassion.

dn2:12.5.eng: “I love my son, sir, Prince Udāyibhadda.

dn2:12.6.pli: Iminā me, bhante, upasamena udayabhaddo kumāro samannāgato hotu yenetarahi upasamena bhikkhusaṅgho samannāgato”ti.
dn2:12.6.eng: May he be blessed with such peace as the Saṅgha of mendicants now enjoys!”

dn2:13.1.pli: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā, bhikkhusaṅghassa añjaliṃ paṇāmetvā, ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
dn2:13.1.eng: Then the king bowed to the Buddha, raised his joined palms toward the Saṅgha, and sat down to one side.

dn2:13.2.pli: Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:

dn2:13.3.eng: “Sir, I’d like to ask you about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”

dn2:13.4.pli: sace me bhagavā okāsaṃ karoti pañhassa veyyākaraṇāyā”ti.

dn2:14.1.eng: “Sir, there are many different professional fields.
dn2:14.1.comm: Most translators render sippa as “craft”. However, the basic meaning of “craft” is skill in doing or making things. What is meant here is a paid occupation regardless of whether it involves making things, i.e. “profession”.

dn2:14.2.pli: seyyathidaṃ—hatthārohā assārohā rathikā dhanuggahā celakā calakā piṇḍadāyakā uggā rājaputtā pakkhandino mahānāgā sūrā cammayodhino dāsikaputtā
dn2:14.2.eng: These include elephant riders, cavalry, charioteers, archers, bannermen, adjutants, food servers, warrior-chiefs, princes, chargers, great warriors, heroes, leather-clad soldiers, and sons of bondservants.
dn2:14.2.comm: These are the professions on Ajātasattu’s mind. The first set of these is defined as branches of the military at AN 7.67.

dn2:14.3.pli: āḷārikā kappakā nhāpakā sūdā mālakārā rajakā pesakārā naḷakārā kumbhakārā gaṇakā muddikā, yāni vā panaññānipi evaṅgatāni puthusippāyatanāni, te diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sippaphalaṃ upajīvanti;
dn2:14.3.eng: They also include bakers, barbers, bathroom attendants, cooks, garland-makers, dyers, embroiderers, basket-makers, potters, accountants, finger-talliers, or those following any similar professions. All these live off the fruits of their profession which are apparent in this very life.
dn2:14.3.comm: The question pertains to right livelihood, the fifth factor of the noble eightfold path.

dn2:14.4.pli: te tena attānaṃ sukhenti pīṇenti, mātāpitaro sukhenti pīṇenti, puttadāraṃ sukhenti pīṇenti, mittāmacce sukhenti pīṇenti, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ patiṭṭhapenti sovaggikaṃ sukhavipākaṃ saggasaṃvattanikaṃ.
dn2:14.4.eng: With that they make themselves happy and pleased. They make their parents, their children and partners, and their friends and colleagues happy and pleased. And they establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.
dn2:14.4.comm: The purpose of right livelihood is to bring happiness in this life and the next.

dn2:14.5.pli: Sakkā nu kho, bhante, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetun”ti?
dn2:14.5.eng: Sir, can you point out a fruit of the ascetic life that’s likewise apparent in this very life?”
dn2:14.5.comm: Ajātasattu’s question only pertains to happiness in this life. He would have seen ascetics living hard and austere lives for the sake of future happiness.

dn2:15.1.pli: “Abhijānāsi no tvaṃ, mahārāja, imaṃ pañhaṃ aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe pucchitā”ti?
dn2:15.1.eng: “Great king, do you recall having asked this question of other ascetics and brahmins?”
dn2:15.1.comm: The term “Great King” (mahārāja) identifies Ajātasattu as the hereditary monarch of a large realm, in contrast with the multiple elected “rulers” of the aristocratic republics such as Vajji and Sakya.

dn2:15.2.pli: “Abhijānāmahaṃ, bhante, imaṃ pañhaṃ aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe pucchitā”ti.

dn2:15.3.pli: “Yathā kathaṃ pana te, mahārāja, byākariṃsu, sace te agaru bhāsassū”ti.
dn2:15.3.eng: “If you wouldn’t mind, great king, tell me how they answered.”
dn2:15.3.comm: As in DN 1:1.4.2, the Buddha begins by asking to hear what others have said.

dn2:15.4.pli: “Na kho me, bhante, garu, yatthassa bhagavā nisinno, bhagavantarūpo vā”ti.
dn2:15.4.eng: “It’s no trouble when someone such as the Blessed One is sitting here.”

dn2:16.1.pli: “Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ yena pūraṇo kassapo tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā pūraṇena kassapena saddhiṃ sammodiṃ.
dn2:16.1.eng: “This one time, sir, I approached Pūraṇa Kassapa and exchanged greetings with him.

dn2:16.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ahaṃ, bhante, pūraṇaṃ kassapaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn2:16.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.
dn2:16.2.comm: As with his meeting with the Buddha, Ajātasattu is respectful but not reverential.

dn2:16.3.pli: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho kassapa, puthusippāyatanāni,

dn2:16.4.pli: seyyathidaṃ—hatthārohā assārohā rathikā dhanuggahā celakā calakā piṇḍadāyakā uggā rājaputtā pakkhandino mahānāgā sūrā cammayodhino dāsikaputtā āḷārikā kappakā nhāpakā sūdā mālakārā rajakā pesakārā naḷakārā kumbhakārā gaṇakā muddikā, yāni vā panaññānipi evaṅgatāni puthusippāyatanāni, te diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sippaphalaṃ upajīvanti;

dn2:16.5.pli: te tena attānaṃ sukhenti pīṇenti, mātāpitaro sukhenti pīṇenti, puttadāraṃ sukhenti pīṇenti, mittāmacce sukhenti pīṇenti, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ patiṭṭhapenti sovaggikaṃ sukhavipākaṃ saggasaṃvattanikaṃ.

dn2:16.6.pli: Sakkā nu kho, bho kassapa, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetun’ti?

dn2:17.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, pūraṇo kassapo maṃ etadavoca:

dn2:17.2.pli: ‘karoto kho, mahārāja, kārayato, chindato chedāpayato, pacato pācāpayato socayato, socāpayato, kilamato kilamāpayato, phandato phandāpayato, pāṇamatipātāpayato, adinnaṃ ādiyato, sandhiṃ chindato, nillopaṃ harato, ekāgārikaṃ karoto, paripanthe tiṭṭhato, paradāraṃ gacchato, musā bhaṇato, karoto na karīyati pāpaṃ. Khurapariyantena cepi cakkena yo imissā pathaviyā pāṇe ekaṃ maṃsakhalaṃ ekaṃ maṃsapuñjaṃ kareyya, natthi tatonidānaṃ pāpaṃ, natthi pāpassa āgamo.
dn2:17.2.eng: ‘Great king, the one who acts does nothing wrong when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. They do nothing wrong when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie. If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
dn2:17.2.comm: This is a denial of the doctrine of kamma. While his doctrine appears to be morally nihilistic, it seems unlikely this was Pūraṇa Kassapa’s full teaching. He may have subscribed to hard determinism, so that we have no choice in what we do. He may also have believed that we should keep moral rules as a social contract, but that this had no effect on the afterlife. | In such contexts, kar- means “punish, inflict” (MN 129:29.2).

dn2:17.3.pli: Dakkhiṇañcepi gaṅgāya tīraṃ gaccheyya hananto ghātento chindanto chedāpento pacanto pācāpento, natthi tatonidānaṃ pāpaṃ, natthi pāpassa āgamo.
dn2:17.3.eng: If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.

dn2:17.4.pli: Uttarañcepi gaṅgāya tīraṃ gaccheyya dadanto dāpento yajanto yajāpento, natthi tatonidānaṃ puññaṃ, natthi puññassa āgamo.
dn2:17.4.eng: If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, no merit comes of that, and no outcome of merit.

dn2:17.5.pli: Dānena damena saṃyamena saccavajjena natthi puññaṃ, natthi puññassa āgamo’ti.
dn2:17.5.eng: In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is no merit or outcome of merit.’

dn2:18.1.pli: Itthaṃ kho me, bhante, pūraṇo kassapo sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno akiriyaṃ byākāsi.
dn2:18.1.eng: And so, when I asked Pūraṇa Kassapa about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with the doctrine of inaction.
dn2:18.1.comm: The unsatisfying nature of the answers given by these teachers is also emphasized at MN 36:48.4.

dn2:18.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṃ vā puṭṭho labujaṃ byākareyya, labujaṃ vā puṭṭho ambaṃ byākareyya;
dn2:18.2.eng: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.
dn2:18.2.comm: Breadfruit is a starchy, fibrous fruit that is, needless to say, very different from a mango.

dn2:18.3.pli: evameva kho me, bhante, pūraṇo kassapo sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno akiriyaṃ byākāsi.

dn2:18.5.pli: ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā vijite vasantaṃ apasādetabbaṃ maññeyyā’ti.
dn2:18.5.eng: ‘How on earth could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’
dn2:18.5.comm: Kings had a duty to protect all religions in their realm, even those with such extreme views.

dn2:18.6.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhante, pūraṇassa kassapassa bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃ nappaṭikkosiṃ.
dn2:18.6.eng: So I neither approved nor rejected that statement of Pūraṇa Kassapa.

dn2:18.7.pli: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano, anattamanavācaṃ anicchāretvā, tameva vācaṃ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ.
dn2:18.7.eng: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.
dn2:18.7.comm: The commentary takes uggahita and nikkujjita as synonyms. Elsewhere, however, nikkujjati always means “overturns”.

dn2:19.0.eng: 3.2. The Doctrine of the Bamboo-staffed Ascetic Gosāla

dn2:19.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ yena makkhali gosālo tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā makkhalinā gosālena saddhiṃ sammodiṃ.
dn2:19.1.eng: This one time, sir, I approached the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla and exchanged greetings with him.

dn2:19.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ahaṃ, bhante, makkhaliṃ gosālaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn2:19.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.

dn2:19.3.pli: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho gosāla, puthusippāyatanāni …pe…

dn2:19.4.pli: sakkā nu kho, bho gosāla, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetun’ti?

dn2:20.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, makkhali gosālo maṃ etadavoca:

dn2:20.2.pli: ‘natthi, mahārāja, hetu natthi paccayo sattānaṃ saṅkilesāya, ahetū apaccayā sattā saṅkilissanti.
dn2:20.2.eng: ‘Great king, there is no cause or reason for the corruption of sentient beings. Sentient beings are corrupted without cause or reason.
dn2:20.2.comm: This denies the principle of causality and the efficacy of action. The vastness and inexplicably of the course of transmigration instils resignation. The fatalistic teachings of the Ājīvikas led to them becoming popular as prognosticators. | This view is attributed to Pūraṇa Kassapa at SN 22.60:2.2.

dn2:20.3.pli: Natthi hetu, natthi paccayo sattānaṃ visuddhiyā,
dn2:20.3.eng: There’s no cause or reason for the purification of sentient beings.

dn2:20.4.eng: Sentient beings are purified without cause or reason.

dn2:20.5.pli: Natthi attakāre, natthi parakāre, natthi purisakāre, natthi balaṃ, natthi vīriyaṃ, natthi purisathāmo, natthi purisaparakkamo.
dn2:20.5.eng: One does not act of one’s own volition, one does not act of another’s volition, one does not act from a person’s volition. There is no power, no energy, no human strength or vigor.
dn2:20.5.comm: The first three phrases, with the Magadhan nominative singular in -e, are unique to this passage. In AN 6.38:1.4 we find the regular nominative form in -o. They are omitted in the otherwise parallel passage at MN 76:13.6.

dn2:20.6.pli: Sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā sabbe jīvā avasā abalā avīriyā niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatā chasvevābhijātīsu sukhadukkhaṃ paṭisaṃvedenti.
dn2:20.6.eng: All sentient beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy. Molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth.
dn2:20.6.comm: For the “six classes of rebirth” see AN 6.57. | The next passage lays out the labyrinthine course through which souls must proceed before their final liberation. Many terms are unclear. The commentary is scathing of this text, seeing it as ignorant and plainly wrong. It is likely, however, that the Pali text misconstrues some of the technical terms. Basham has attempted to reconstruct their meaning, relying heavily on the Jain account in the Bhagavatī Sūtra (History and Doctrines of the Ājīvakas, p. 240 ff). My translation, drawing from Basham, assumes that the underlying scheme was coherent. For the commentarial account, see Bodhi.

dn2:20.7.pli: Cuddasa kho panimāni yonipamukhasatasahassāni saṭṭhi ca satāni cha ca satāni pañca ca kammuno satāni pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammāni kamme ca aḍḍhakamme ca dvaṭṭhipaṭipadā dvaṭṭhantarakappā chaḷābhijātiyo aṭṭha purisabhūmiyo ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasate ekūnapaññāsa paribbājakasate ekūnapaññāsa nāgāvāsasate vīse indriyasate tiṃse nirayasate chattiṃsa rajodhātuyo satta saññīgabbhā satta asaññīgabbhā satta nigaṇṭhigabbhā satta devā satta mānusā satta pisācā satta sarā satta pavuṭā satta pavuṭasatāni satta papātā satta papātasatāni satta supinā satta supinasatāni cullāsīti mahākappino satasahassāni, yāni bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karissanti.
dn2:20.7.eng: There are 1.4 million main wombs, and 6,000, and 600; 500 deeds, and five, and three; deeds and half-deeds; 62 paths of practice, 62 sub-eons, six classes of rebirth, and eight stages in a person’s life; 4,900 Ājīvaka ascetics, 4,900 wanderers, and 4,900 dragon abodes; 2,000 lordships, 3,000 hells, and 36 realms of dusky sky; seven percipient embryos, seven non-percipient embryos, seven knotless embryos, seven gods, seven mental heavens, seven goblins, seven streams, seven castoff incarnations and 700 castoff incarnations, seven downfalls and 700 downfalls, seven dreams and 700 dreams, and 8.4 million great eons—through all of which the foolish and the astute transmigrate before making an end of suffering.
dn2:20.7.comm: The “wombs” are probably species through which one transmigrates. | The many kinds of deeds classified by Ājīvakas have only contingent effect, as the ultimate course of transmigration is fixed. It seems the “half deeds” are performed by mind alone. | The 62 “paths of practice” perhaps echo the 62 wrong views of DN 1, indicating the kammic destinies of such practices. | The set of “4,900” (i.e. 7 × 700) refers to the number of times one will be reborn in each of these states. | Indriya perhaps means “lordship”, i.e. rulership in heaven or earth. | Rajodhātu perhaps relates to the Vedic sense of rajo as “dusky skies”, the cloudy regions of the lower atmosphere through which gods travel on their way from heaven. These are counted as three, six, or many. | The next set of sevens partially overlaps with a list in the Bhagavatī Sūtra, and appears to list kinds of rebirth experienced near the end of transmigration. | The Pali commentary says “non-percipient embryos” are plants, but it could be the “non-percipient beings”. | “Knotless embryos” (nigaṇṭhigabbha) perhaps refers to those born free of attachments in certain high heavens. | Pali mānusa (“human”) should probably be mānasa (“mental”), a name for an Ājīvaka heaven. But māṇasa and sara (“streams”) are also Ājīvaka terms for inconceivably long stretches of time in saṁsara. | Pavuṭā probably refers to the “castoff incarnations” (paüṭṭaparihāra), seven sages in whom, according to the Bhagavatī Sūtra, Gosāla had been born before his last life. | Papāta is “cliff”, here probably meaning “downfall” into a lower realm. | The significance of “dreams” here is unclear; perhaps they are portents.

dn2:20.8.pli: Tattha natthi “imināhaṃ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā aparipakkaṃ vā kammaṃ paripācessāmi, paripakkaṃ vā kammaṃ phussa phussa byantiṃ karissāmī”ti hevaṃ natthi.
dn2:20.8.eng: And here there is no such thing as this: “By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life I shall force unripened deeds to bear their fruit, or eliminate old deeds by experiencing their results little by little,” for that cannot be.
dn2:20.8.comm: To “force unripened deeds to bear their fruit” by means of “fervent austerity” (tapas) is a Jain practice, whereas to “eliminate old deeds by experiencing their results little by little” is distinguished from the Jain view at AN 3.74.

dn2:20.9.pli: Doṇamite sukhadukkhe pariyantakate saṃsāre, natthi hāyanavaḍḍhane, natthi ukkaṃsāvakaṃse.
dn2:20.9.eng: Pleasure and pain are allotted. Transmigration lasts only for a limited period, so there’s no increase or decrease, no getting better or worse.

dn2:20.10.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma suttaguḷe khitte nibbeṭhiyamānameva paleti;
dn2:20.10.eng: It’s like how, when you toss a ball of string, it rolls away unraveling.

dn2:20.11.pli: evameva bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṃsaritvā dukkhassantaṃ karissantī’ti.
dn2:20.11.eng: In the same way, after transmigrating the foolish and the astute will make an end of suffering.’

dn2:21.1.pli: Itthaṃ kho me, bhante, makkhali gosālo sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno saṃsārasuddhiṃ byākāsi.
dn2:21.1.eng: And so, when I asked the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with the doctrine of purification through transmigration.

dn2:21.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṃ vā puṭṭho labujaṃ byākareyya, labujaṃ vā puṭṭho ambaṃ byākareyya;
dn2:21.2.eng: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.

dn2:21.3.pli: evameva kho me, bhante, makkhali gosālo sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno saṃsārasuddhiṃ byākāsi.

dn2:21.5.pli: ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā vijite vasantaṃ apasādetabbaṃ maññeyyā’ti.
dn2:21.5.eng: ‘How on earth could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’

dn2:21.6.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhante, makkhalissa gosālassa bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃ nappaṭikkosiṃ.
dn2:21.6.eng: So I neither approved nor rejected that statement of the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla.

dn2:21.7.pli: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano, anattamanavācaṃ anicchāretvā, tameva vācaṃ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ.
dn2:21.7.eng: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.

dn2:22.0.eng: 3.3. The Doctrine of Ajita of the Hair Blanket

dn2:22.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ yena ajito kesakambalo tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā ajitena kesakambalena saddhiṃ sammodiṃ.
dn2:22.1.eng: This one time, sir, I approached Ajita of the hair blanket and exchanged greetings with him.

dn2:22.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ahaṃ, bhante, ajitaṃ kesakambalaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn2:22.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.

dn2:22.3.pli: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho ajita, puthusippāyatanāni …pe…

dn2:22.4.pli: sakkā nu kho, bho ajita, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetun’ti?

dn2:23.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, ajito kesakambalo maṃ etadavoca:

dn2:23.2.pli: ‘natthi, mahārāja, dinnaṃ, natthi yiṭṭhaṃ, natthi hutaṃ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko, natthi ayaṃ loko, natthi paro loko, natthi mātā, natthi pitā, natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā, ye imañca lokaṃ parañca lokaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedenti.
dn2:23.2.eng: ‘Great king, there is no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.
dn2:23.2.comm: The denial of “mother and father” is usually interpreted as the denial of moral duty towards one’s parents. However, I think it is a doctrine of conception which denies that a child is created by the mother and father. Rather, the child is produced by the four elements, with parents as mere instigators and incubators.

dn2:23.3.pli: Cātumahābhūtiko ayaṃ puriso, yadā kālaṃ karoti, pathavī pathavikāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati, āpo āpokāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati, tejo tejokāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati, vāyo vāyokāyaṃ anupeti anupagacchati, ākāsaṃ indriyāni saṅkamanti.
dn2:23.3.eng: This person is made up of the four principal states. When they die, the earth in their body merges and coalesces with the substance of earth. The water in their body merges and coalesces with the substance of water. The fire in their body merges and coalesces with the substance of fire. The air in their body merges and coalesces with the substance of air. The faculties are transferred to space.
dn2:23.3.comm: This is a materialist analysis of the person. | The word kāya (“substance”) is central to Jainism. Ācārāṅgasūtra 8.1.11 speaks of the “substances” of earth, water, fire, and air as being imbued with life so one should avoid damaging them. | The Buddha’s use of mahābhūtā (“principal states”) responds to Yājñavalkya’s core teaching at Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 2.4.12, where the several “states” or “real entities” (bhūtā)—namely the diverse manifestations of creation—arise from and dissolve into the “principal state” (mahābhūta) of the Self, singular and infinite. For the Buddha, the “principal states” are themselves plural, as there is no underlying singular reality. Later Sanskrit literature lists the “five states” (pañcabhūta) as earth, water, fire, air, and space.

dn2:23.4.eng: Four men with a bier carry away the corpse.

dn2:23.5.eng: Their footprints show the way to the cremation ground.

dn2:23.6.eng: The bones become bleached. Offerings dedicated to the gods end in ashes.

dn2:23.7.eng: Giving is a doctrine of morons.

dn2:23.8.pli: Tesaṃ tucchaṃ musā vilāpo ye keci atthikavādaṃ vadanti.
dn2:23.8.eng: When anyone affirms a positive teaching it’s just hollow, false nonsense.

dn2:23.9.pli: Bāle ca paṇḍite ca kāyassa bhedā ucchijjanti vinassanti, na honti paraṃ maraṇā’ti.
dn2:23.9.eng: Both the foolish and the astute are annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and don’t exist after death.’

dn2:24.1.pli: Itthaṃ kho me, bhante, ajito kesakambalo sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno ucchedaṃ byākāsi.
dn2:24.1.eng: And so, when I asked Ajita of the hair blanket about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with the doctrine of annihilationism.

dn2:24.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṃ vā puṭṭho labujaṃ byākareyya, labujaṃ vā puṭṭho ambaṃ byākareyya;
dn2:24.2.eng: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.

dn2:24.3.pli: evameva kho me, bhante, ajito kesakambalo sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno ucchedaṃ byākāsi.

dn2:24.5.pli: ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā vijite vasantaṃ apasādetabbaṃ maññeyyā’ti.
dn2:24.5.eng: ‘How on earth could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’

dn2:24.6.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhante, ajitassa kesakambalassa bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃ nappaṭikkosiṃ.
dn2:24.6.eng: So I neither approved nor rejected that statement of Ajita of the hair blanket.

dn2:24.7.pli: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano anattamanavācaṃ anicchāretvā tameva vācaṃ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ.
dn2:24.7.eng: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.

dn2:25.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ yena pakudho kaccāyano tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā pakudhena kaccāyanena saddhiṃ sammodiṃ.
dn2:25.1.eng: This one time, sir, I approached Pakudha Kaccāyana and exchanged greetings with him.

dn2:25.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ahaṃ, bhante, pakudhaṃ kaccāyanaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn2:25.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.

dn2:25.3.pli: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho kaccāyana, puthusippāyatanāni …pe…

dn2:25.4.pli: sakkā nu kho, bho kaccāyana, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetun’ti?

dn2:26.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, pakudho kaccāyano maṃ etadavoca:

dn2:26.2.pli: ‘sattime, mahārāja, kāyā akaṭā akaṭavidhā animmitā animmātā vañjhā kūṭaṭṭhā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā.
dn2:26.2.eng: ‘Great king, these seven substances are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
dn2:26.2.comm: This is a reductive atomism. It argues that since all things are made of the seven fundamental substances (kāya), higher-order entities have no significance.

dn2:26.3.pli: Te na iñjanti, na vipariṇamanti, na aññamaññaṃ byābādhenti, nālaṃ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā.
dn2:26.3.eng: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other.

dn2:26.5.pli: Pathavikāyo, āpokāyo, tejokāyo, vāyokāyo, sukhe, dukkhe, jīve sattame—
dn2:26.5.eng: The substances of earth, water, fire, air; pleasure, pain, and the soul is the seventh.
dn2:26.5.comm: Unlike the materialism of Ajita Kesakambala, one of the basic substances is the soul. He uses jīva, the same term used by the Jains, rather than attā as preferred by the brahmins. Likewise, the Jains held a similar doctrine of six uncreated and eternal “substances” (kāya or dravya): soul, the media for motion and rest, matter, space, and time.

dn2:26.6.pli: ime satta kāyā akaṭā akaṭavidhā animmitā animmātā vañjhā kūṭaṭṭhā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā.
dn2:26.6.eng: These seven substances are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.

dn2:26.7.pli: Te na iñjanti, na vipariṇamanti, na aññamaññaṃ byābādhenti, nālaṃ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā.
dn2:26.7.eng: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other.

dn2:26.8.pli: Tattha natthi hantā vā ghātetā vā, sotā vā sāvetā vā, viññātā vā viññāpetā vā.
dn2:26.8.eng: And here there is no-one who kills or who makes others kill; no-one who learns or who educates others; no-one who understands or who helps others understand.

dn2:26.9.pli: Yopi tiṇhena satthena sīsaṃ chindati, na koci kiñci jīvitā voropeti;
dn2:26.9.eng: If you chop off someone’s head with a sharp sword, you don’t take anyone’s life.

dn2:26.10.eng: The sword simply passes through the gap between the seven substances.’

dn2:27.1.pli: Itthaṃ kho me, bhante, pakudho kaccāyano sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno aññena aññaṃ byākāsi.
dn2:27.1.eng: And so, when I asked Pakudha Kaccāyana about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with something else entirely.

dn2:27.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṃ vā puṭṭho labujaṃ byākareyya, labujaṃ vā puṭṭho ambaṃ byākareyya;
dn2:27.2.eng: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.

dn2:27.3.pli: evameva kho me, bhante, pakudho kaccāyano sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno aññena aññaṃ byākāsi.

dn2:27.5.pli: ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā vijite vasantaṃ apasādetabbaṃ maññeyyā’ti.
dn2:27.5.eng: ‘How on earth could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’

dn2:27.6.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhante, pakudhassa kaccāyanassa bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃ nappaṭikkosiṃ,
dn2:27.6.eng: So I neither approved nor rejected that statement of Pakudha Kaccāyana.

dn2:27.7.pli: anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano, anattamanavācaṃ anicchāretvā tameva vācaṃ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ.
dn2:27.7.eng: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.

dn2:28.0.eng: 3.5. The Doctrine of the Jain Ascetic of the Ñātika Clan

dn2:28.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ yena nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā nigaṇṭhena nāṭaputtena saddhiṃ sammodiṃ.
dn2:28.1.eng: This one time, sir, I approached the Jain Ñātika and exchanged greetings with him.

dn2:28.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ahaṃ, bhante, nigaṇṭhaṃ nāṭaputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn2:28.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.

dn2:28.3.pli: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho aggivessana, puthusippāyatanāni …pe…

dn2:28.4.pli: sakkā nu kho, bho aggivessana, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetun’ti?

dn2:29.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto maṃ etadavoca:

dn2:29.2.eng: ‘Great king, consider a Jain ascetic who is restrained in the fourfold constraint.
dn2:29.2.comm: While this is a genuine Jain teaching, it has not been identified as a “fourfold restraint”. DN 25:16.3 preserves another “fourfold restraint” that is closer to that found in Jainism. At MN 12:44.1 the Buddha says he once practiced a “four-factored spiritual path” that consisted of Jain-like austerities.

dn2:29.3.eng: And how is a Jain ascetic restrained in the fourfold constraint?

dn2:29.4.pli: Idha, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho sabbavārivārito ca hoti, sabbavāriyutto ca, sabbavāridhuto ca, sabbavāriphuṭo ca.
dn2:29.4.eng: It’s when a Jain ascetic is restrained in all that is to be restrained, is bridled in all that is to be restrained, has shaken off evil in all that is to be restrained, and is curbed in all that is to be restrained.
dn2:29.4.comm: At Isibhāsiyāiṁ 29.19, Vardhamāna (Mahāvīra) teaches that a sage is savva-vārīhiṁ vārie, “restrained in all restraints”, which clearly parallels our current passage. In that passage, “restraint” refers to stopping the influx of defilements through the five senses, neither delighting in the pleasant nor loathing the unpleasant. Similarly we find vāriya-savva-vāri in the commentary to Sūyagaḍa 1.6.28. | Read vāri as future passive participle (cf. Sanskrit vārya). | Dhuta in the sense “shaken off (evil by means of ascetic practices)” is a characteristic Jain term. | For sabbavāriphuṭo compare ophuṭo at MN 99:15.5. In both cases phuṭ appears in a string of terms from the root var, and is possibly a corrupted form, or at least has the same meaning.

dn2:29.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvuto hoti.
dn2:29.5.eng: That’s how a Jain ascetic is restrained in the fourfold constraint.

dn2:29.6.pli: Yato kho, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho evaṃ cātuyāmasaṃvarasaṃvuto hoti;
dn2:29.6.eng: When a Jain ascetic is restrained in the fourfold constraint,

dn2:29.7.pli: ayaṃ vuccati, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho gatatto ca yatatto ca ṭhitatto cā’ti.
dn2:29.7.eng: they’re called a knotless one who is self-realized, self-controlled, and steadfast.’

dn2:30.1.pli: Itthaṃ kho me, bhante, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno cātuyāmasaṃvaraṃ byākāsi.
dn2:30.1.eng: And so, when I asked the Jain Ñātika about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with the fourfold constraint.

dn2:30.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṃ vā puṭṭho labujaṃ byākareyya, labujaṃ vā puṭṭho ambaṃ byākareyya;
dn2:30.2.eng: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.

dn2:30.3.pli: evameva kho me, bhante, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno cātuyāmasaṃvaraṃ byākāsi.

dn2:30.5.pli: ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā vijite vasantaṃ apasādetabbaṃ maññeyyā’ti.
dn2:30.5.eng: ‘How on earth could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’

dn2:30.6.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhante, nigaṇṭhassa nāṭaputtassa bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃ nappaṭikkosiṃ.
dn2:30.6.eng: So I neither approved nor rejected that statement of the Jain Ñātika.

dn2:30.7.pli: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano anattamanavācaṃ anicchāretvā tameva vācaṃ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ.
dn2:30.7.eng: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.

dn2:31.1.pli: Ekamidāhaṃ, bhante, samayaṃ yena sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā sañcayena belaṭṭhaputtena saddhiṃ sammodiṃ.
dn2:31.1.eng: This one time, sir, I approached Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta and exchanged greetings with him.

dn2:31.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho ahaṃ, bhante, sañcayaṃ belaṭṭhaputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
dn2:31.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side, and asked him the same question.

dn2:31.3.pli: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho sañcaya, puthusippāyatanāni …pe…

dn2:31.4.pli: sakkā nu kho, bho sañcaya, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetun’ti?

dn2:32.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, bhante, sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto maṃ etadavoca:

dn2:32.2.pli: ‘atthi paro lokoti iti ce maṃ pucchasi, atthi paro lokoti iti ce me assa, atthi paro lokoti iti te naṃ byākareyyaṃ.
dn2:32.2.eng: ‘Suppose you were to ask me whether there is another world. If I believed that to be the case, I would say so.

dn2:32.3.pli: Evantipi me no, tathātipi me no, aññathātipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me no.
dn2:32.3.eng: But I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.
dn2:32.3.comm: This places him among the “endless flip-floppers” of DN 1:2.23.1. However, we do not know on which of the four grounds he justified his evasiveness.

dn2:32.4.eng: Suppose you were to ask me whether there is no other world …

dn2:32.5.pli: atthi ca natthi ca paro loko …pe…
dn2:32.5.eng: whether there both is and is not another world …

dn2:32.6.eng: whether there neither is nor is not another world …

dn2:32.7.eng: whether there are beings who are reborn spontaneously …

dn2:32.8.eng: whether there are no beings who are reborn spontaneously …

dn2:32.9.pli: atthi ca natthi ca sattā opapātikā …pe…
dn2:32.9.eng: whether there both are and are not beings who are reborn spontaneously …

dn2:32.10.eng: whether there neither are nor are not beings who are reborn spontaneously …

dn2:32.11.eng: whether there is fruit and result of good and bad deeds …

dn2:32.12.eng: whether there is no fruit and result of good and bad deeds …

dn2:32.13.pli: atthi ca natthi ca sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko …pe…
dn2:32.13.eng: whether there both is and is not fruit and result of good and bad deeds …

dn2:32.14.pli: nevatthi na natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṃ kammānaṃ phalaṃ vipāko …pe…
dn2:32.14.eng: whether there neither is nor is not fruit and result of good and bad deeds …

dn2:32.15.eng: whether a realized one still exists after death …

dn2:32.16.eng: whether a realized one no longer exists after death …

dn2:32.17.pli: hoti ca na ca hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇā …pe…
dn2:32.17.eng: whether a realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death …

dn2:32.18.pli: neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti iti ce maṃ pucchasi, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti iti ce me assa, neva hoti na na hoti tathāgato paraṃ maraṇāti iti te naṃ byākareyyaṃ.
dn2:32.18.eng: whether a realized one neither exists nor doesn’t exist after death. If I believed that to be the case, I would say so.

dn2:32.19.pli: Evantipi me no, tathātipi me no, aññathātipi me no, notipi me no, no notipi me no’ti.
dn2:32.19.eng: But I don’t say it’s like this. I don’t say it’s like that. I don’t say it’s otherwise. I don’t say it’s not so. And I don’t deny it’s not so.’

dn2:33.1.pli: Itthaṃ kho me, bhante, sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno vikkhepaṃ byākāsi.
dn2:33.1.eng: And so, when I asked Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life, he answered with flip-flopping.

dn2:33.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṃ vā puṭṭho labujaṃ byākareyya, labujaṃ vā puṭṭho ambaṃ byākareyya;
dn2:33.2.eng: It was like someone who, when asked about a mango, answered with a breadfruit, or when asked about a breadfruit, answered with a mango.

dn2:33.3.pli: evameva kho me, bhante, sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno vikkhepaṃ byākāsi.

dn2:33.5.eng: ‘This is the most foolish and stupid of all these ascetics and brahmins!

dn2:33.6.pli: Kathañhi nāma sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ puṭṭho samāno vikkhepaṃ byākarissatī’ti.
dn2:33.6.eng: How on earth can he answer with flip-flopping when asked about the fruits of the ascetic life apparent in the present life?’

dn2:33.8.pli: ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṃ vā brāhmaṇaṃ vā vijite vasantaṃ apasādetabbaṃ maññeyyā’ti.
dn2:33.8.eng: ‘How on earth could one such as I presume to rebuke an ascetic or brahmin living in my realm?’

dn2:33.9.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhante, sañcayassa belaṭṭhaputtassa bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃ nappaṭikkosiṃ.
dn2:33.9.eng: So I neither approved nor rejected that statement of Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta.

dn2:33.10.pli: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano anattamanavācaṃ anicchāretvā tameva vācaṃ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ.
dn2:33.10.eng: I was displeased, but did not express my displeasure. Neither accepting what he said nor contradicting it, I got up from my seat and left.

dn2:34.0.1.eng: 4. The Fruits of the Ascetic Life

dn2:34.0.2.eng: 4.1. The First Fruit of the Ascetic Life

dn2:34.1.eng: And so I ask the Buddha:

dn2:34.2.eng: Sir, there are many different professional fields.

dn2:34.3.pli: seyyathidaṃ—hatthārohā assārohā rathikā dhanuggahā celakā calakā piṇḍadāyakā uggā rājaputtā pakkhandino mahānāgā sūrā cammayodhino dāsikaputtā
dn2:34.3.eng: These include elephant riders, cavalry, charioteers, archers, bannermen, adjutants, food servers, warrior-chiefs, princes, chargers, great warriors, heroes, leather-clad soldiers, and sons of bondservants.

dn2:34.4.pli: āḷārikā kappakā nhāpakā sūdā mālakārā rajakā pesakārā naḷakārā kumbhakārā gaṇakā muddikā, yāni vā panaññānipi evaṅgatāni puthusippāyatanāni, te diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sippaphalaṃ upajīvanti,
dn2:34.4.eng: They also include bakers, barbers, bathroom attendants, cooks, garland-makers, dyers, embroiderers, basket-makers, potters, accountants, finger-talliers, or those following any similar professions. All these live off the fruits of their profession which are apparent in this very life.

dn2:34.5.pli: te tena attānaṃ sukhenti pīṇenti, mātāpitaro sukhenti pīṇenti, puttadāraṃ sukhenti pīṇenti, mittāmacce sukhenti pīṇenti, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṃ dakkhiṇaṃ patiṭṭhapenti sovaggikaṃ sukhavipākaṃ saggasaṃvattanikaṃ.
dn2:34.5.eng: With that they make themselves happy and pleased. They make their parents, their children and partners, and their friends and colleagues happy and pleased. And they establish an uplifting religious donation for ascetics and brahmins that’s conducive to heaven, ripens in happiness, and leads to heaven.

dn2:34.6.pli: Sakkā nu kho, bhante, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetun’”ti?
dn2:34.6.eng: Sir, can you point out a fruit of the ascetic life that’s likewise apparent in this very life?”

dn2:34.7.comm: The Buddha answers directly, with confidence. This whole passage is a masterclass in effective dialogue.

dn2:34.8.pli: Tena hi, mahārāja, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā te khameyya, tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.
dn2:34.8.eng: Well then, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
dn2:34.8.comm: He engages Ajātasattu rather than lecturing him.

dn2:35.1.eng: What do you think, great king?

dn2:35.2.pli: idha te assa puriso dāso kammakāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako.
dn2:35.2.eng: Suppose you had a person who was a bondservant, a worker. They get up before you and go to bed after you, and are obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely, and gazing up at your face.
dn2:35.2.comm: See mukhaṁ ullokentī at MN 79 and SN 56.39.

dn2:35.4.pli: ‘acchariyaṃ, vata bho, abbhutaṃ, vata bho, puññānaṃ gati, puññānaṃ vipāko.
dn2:35.4.eng: ‘The outcome and result of good deeds is just so incredible, so amazing!
dn2:35.4.comm: Even a servant believed in the doctrine of kamma.

dn2:35.5.pli: Ayañhi rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto manusso; ahampi manusso.
dn2:35.5.eng: For this King Ajātasattu is a human being, and so am I.
dn2:35.5.comm: There is no question of the divinity of kings.

dn2:35.6.pli: Ayañhi rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti, devo maññe.
dn2:35.6.eng: Yet he amuses himself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation as if he were a god.

dn2:35.7.pli: Ahaṃ panamhissa dāso kammakāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako.
dn2:35.7.eng: Whereas I’m his bondservant, his worker. I get up before him and go to bed after him, and am obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely, and gazing up at his face.

dn2:35.8.eng: I really should do good deeds.
dn2:35.8.comm: The doctrine of kamma leads to living a better life, not stewing in resentment.

dn2:35.9.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyan’ti.
dn2:35.9.eng: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
dn2:35.9.comm: Kd 1:47.1.1 penalizes the ordination of bondservants or slaves, despite the fact that Ajātasattu’s father, Bimbisāra, had ordered that no action was to be taken against any bondservant who ordained under the Buddha.

dn2:35.10.pli: So aparena samayena kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyya.
dn2:35.10.eng: After some time, that is what they do.

dn2:35.11.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno kāyena saṃvuto vihareyya, vācāya saṃvuto vihareyya, manasā saṃvuto vihareyya, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke.
dn2:35.11.eng: Having gone forth they’d live restrained in body, speech, and mind, living content with nothing more than food and clothes, delighting in seclusion.
dn2:35.11.comm: Here the Buddha foreshadows the larger themes detailed later.

dn2:35.12.eng: And suppose your men were to report all this to you.

dn2:35.13.pli: ‘yagghe, deva, jāneyyāsi, yo te so puriso dāso kammakāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako;

dn2:35.14.pli: so, deva, kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.

dn2:35.15.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno kāyena saṃvuto viharati, vācāya saṃvuto viharati, manasā saṃvuto viharati, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke’ti.

dn2:35.17.pli: ‘etu me, bho, so puriso, punadeva hotu dāso kammakāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako’”ti?
dn2:35.17.eng: ‘Bring that person to me! Let them once more be my bondservant, my worker’?”

dn2:36.2.pli: Atha kho naṃ mayameva abhivādeyyāmapi, paccuṭṭheyyāmapi, āsanenapi nimanteyyāma, abhinimanteyyāmapi naṃ cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi, dhammikampissa rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidaheyyāmā”ti.
dn2:36.2.eng: Rather, I would bow to them, rise in their presence, and offer them a seat. I’d invite them to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And I’d organize their lawful guarding and protection.”
dn2:36.2.comm: Even under a king so compromised as Ajātasattu,  a runaway slave who has ordained is rewarded not punished.

dn2:36.4.pli: yadi evaṃ sante hoti vā sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ no vā”ti?
dn2:36.4.eng: If this is so, is there a fruit of the ascetic life apparent in the present life or not?”
dn2:36.4.comm: In contrast with the former teachers, the Buddha gives a clear answer in terms that Ajātasattu would understand.

dn2:36.5.pli: “Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante hoti sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalan”ti.
dn2:36.5.comm: The Buddha establishes common ground with the king before venturing into deeper waters.

dn2:36.6.pli: “Idaṃ kho te, mahārāja, mayā paṭhamaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññattan”ti.
dn2:36.6.eng: “This is the first fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in this very life, which I point out to you.”

dn2:37.0.eng: 4.2. The Second Fruit of the Ascetic Life

dn2:37.1.pli: “Sakkā pana, bhante, aññampi evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetun”ti?
dn2:37.1.eng: “But sir, can you point out another fruit of the ascetic life that’s likewise apparent in this very life?”
dn2:37.1.comm: By starting with a very basic and obvious fruit, the Buddha stimulates Ajātasattu to seek a deeper answer.

dn2:37.3.pli: Tena hi, mahārāja, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā te khameyya, tathā naṃ byākareyyāsi.
dn2:37.3.eng: Well then, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.

dn2:37.4.eng: What do you think, great king?

dn2:37.5.pli: idha te assa puriso kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako.
dn2:37.5.eng: Suppose you had a person who was a farmer, a householder, a hard worker, someone who builds up their capital.
dn2:37.5.comm: Karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako is a unique phrase. For karakāraka, compare MN 57:2.3, where a naked ascetic “does a hard thing”. Rāsi means “heap” (of grain or wealth according to the commentary).

dn2:37.7.pli: ‘acchariyaṃ vata bho, abbhutaṃ vata bho, puññānaṃ gati, puññānaṃ vipāko.
dn2:37.7.eng: ‘The outcome and result of good deeds is just so incredible, so amazing!

dn2:37.8.pli: Ayañhi rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto manusso, ahampi manusso.
dn2:37.8.eng: For this King Ajātasattu is a human being, and so am I.

dn2:37.9.pli: Ayañhi rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti, devo maññe.
dn2:37.9.eng: Yet he amuses himself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation as if he were a god.

dn2:37.10.pli: Ahaṃ panamhissa kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako.
dn2:37.10.eng: Whereas I’m a farmer, a householder, a hard worker, someone who builds up their capital.

dn2:37.11.eng: I really should do good deeds.

dn2:37.12.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyan’ti.
dn2:37.12.eng: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

dn2:37.13.pli: So aparena samayena appaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya, appaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyya.
dn2:37.13.eng: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They’d shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
dn2:37.13.comm: The bonded servant had no wealth or family to renounce, but the worker does.

dn2:37.14.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno kāyena saṃvuto vihareyya, vācāya saṃvuto vihareyya, manasā saṃvuto vihareyya, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke.
dn2:37.14.eng: Having gone forth they’d live restrained in body, speech, and mind, living content with nothing more than food and clothes, delighting in seclusion.

dn2:37.15.eng: And suppose your men were to report all this to you.

dn2:37.16.pli: ‘yagghe, deva, jāneyyāsi, yo te so puriso kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako;

dn2:37.17.pli: so deva kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito.

dn2:37.18.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno kāyena saṃvuto viharati, vācāya saṃvuto viharati, manasā saṃvuto viharati, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke’ti.

dn2:37.20.pli: ‘etu me, bho, so puriso, punadeva hotu kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako’”ti?
dn2:37.20.eng: ‘Bring that person to me! Let them once more be a farmer, a householder, a hard worker, someone who builds up their capital’?”

dn2:38.2.pli: Atha kho naṃ mayameva abhivādeyyāmapi, paccuṭṭheyyāmapi, āsanenapi nimanteyyāma, abhinimanteyyāmapi naṃ cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi, dhammikampissa rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṃ saṃvidaheyyāmā”ti.
dn2:38.2.eng: Rather, I would bow to them, rise in their presence, and offer them a seat. I’d invite them to accept robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick. And I’d organize their lawful guarding and protection.”

dn2:38.4.pli: Yadi evaṃ sante hoti vā sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ no vā”ti?
dn2:38.4.eng: If this is so, is there a fruit of the ascetic life apparent in the present life or not?”

dn2:38.5.pli: “Addhā kho, bhante, evaṃ sante hoti sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalan”ti.

dn2:38.6.pli: “Idaṃ kho te, mahārāja, mayā dutiyaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññattan”ti.
dn2:38.6.eng: “This is the second fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in this very life, which I point out to you.”

dn2:39.0.eng: 4.3. The Finer Fruits of the Ascetic Life

dn2:39.1.pli: “Sakkā pana, bhante, aññampi diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ paññapetuṃ imehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañcā”ti?
dn2:39.1.eng: “But sir, can you point out a fruit of the ascetic life that’s apparent in this very life which is better and finer than these?”

dn2:39.3.pli: Tena hi, mahārāja, suṇohi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
dn2:39.3.eng: Well then, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
dn2:39.3.comm: Having established the king’s genuine interest and understanding, the Buddha prepares him for the long discourse to follow.

dn2:39.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavato paccassosi.

dn2:40.1.pli: “idha, mahārāja, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṃ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṃ buddho bhagavā.
dn2:40.1.eng: “Consider when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those fit for training, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
dn2:40.1.comm: This is the start of the teaching on the Gradual Training, encompassing ethics (sīla), meditation (samādhi), and wisdom (paññā). Only the ethics portion appeared in the Brahmajālasutta, while all three are restated in all the remaining suttas of this chapter, although in truncated form. | It is exceedingly rare for a Buddha to appear.

dn2:40.2.pli: So imaṃ lokaṃ sadevakaṃ samārakaṃ sabrahmakaṃ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṃ pajaṃ sadevamanussaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
dn2:40.2.eng: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
dn2:40.2.comm: The Buddha realizes the truth by his own understanding, not through divine intervention or other metaphysical means.

dn2:40.3.pli: So dhammaṃ deseti ādikalyāṇaṃ majjhekalyāṇaṃ pariyosānakalyāṇaṃ sātthaṃ sabyañjanaṃ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ pakāseti.
dn2:40.3.eng: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
dn2:40.3.comm: It is good when first heard, when practicing, and when one has realized the fruits.

dn2:41.1.pli: Taṃ dhammaṃ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṃ vā kule paccājāto.
dn2:41.1.eng: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
dn2:41.1.comm: The word “householder” (gahapati) informally refers to any lay person, but more specifically indicates someone who owns a house, i.e. a person of standing. The renunciate life is not just for slaves or workers wishing to escape their station.

dn2:41.2.pli: So taṃ dhammaṃ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṃ paṭilabhati.
dn2:41.2.eng: They gain faith in the Realized One

dn2:41.3.pli: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:

dn2:41.4.eng: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.

dn2:41.5.pli: Nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ.
dn2:41.5.eng: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.

dn2:41.6.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyan’ti.
dn2:41.6.eng: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

dn2:41.7.pli: So aparena samayena appaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā bhogakkhandhaṃ pahāya appaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya mahantaṃ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṃ pahāya kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajati.
dn2:41.7.eng: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

dn2:42.1.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno pātimokkhasaṃvarasaṃvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato kusalena, parisuddhājīvo sīlasampanno, indriyesu guttadvāro, satisampajaññena samannāgato, santuṭṭho.
dn2:42.1.eng: Once they’ve gone forth, they live restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken. They act skillfully by body and speech. They’re purified in livelihood and accomplished in ethical conduct. They guard the sense doors, have mindfulness and situational awareness, and are content.
dn2:42.1.comm: This serves as a table of contents for the teachings to come. | Nowadays, the “monastic code” (pātimokkha) means the list of rules for monks and nuns found in the Vinayapiṭaka. In the early texts, however, it has three main meanings. Sometimes it does refer to the list of rules, as at AN 10.36:1.6. Here it refers to the code of conduct that follows, which is a non-legalistic set of guidelines that preceded the Vinayapiṭaka. At DN 14:3.28.1 it refers to the verses summarizing monastic conduct known as the “Ovāda Pātimokkha”.

dn2:43.1.eng: And how, great king, is a mendicant accomplished in ethics?

dn2:43.2.pli: Idha, mahārāja, bhikkhu pāṇātipātaṃ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti. Nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.
dn2:43.2.eng: It’s when a mendicant gives up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
dn2:43.2.comm: While the precept includes any living creature, if a monastic murders a human being they are immediately and permanently expelled.

dn2:43.4.pli: Adinnādānaṃ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharati.
dn2:43.4.eng: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
dn2:43.4.comm: To steal anything of substantial value is an expulsion offence.

dn2:43.6.pli: Abrahmacariyaṃ pahāya brahmacārī hoti ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā.
dn2:43.6.eng: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
dn2:43.6.comm: Buddhist monastics are forbidden from any form of sexual activity. To engage in penetrative intercourse is an expulsion offence.

dn2:44.1.pli: Musāvādaṃ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṃvādako lokassa.
dn2:44.1.eng: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.
dn2:44.1.comm: While any form of lying is forbidden, if a monastic falsely claims states of enlightenment or deep meditation they are expelled.

dn2:44.3.pli: Pisuṇaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti; ito sutvā na amutra akkhātā imesaṃ bhedāya; amutra vā sutvā na imesaṃ akkhātā, amūsaṃ bhedāya. Iti bhinnānaṃ vā sandhātā, sahitānaṃ vā anuppadātā, samaggārāmo samaggarato samagganandī samaggakaraṇiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
dn2:44.3.eng: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided and support those who are united, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.

dn2:44.5.pli: Pharusaṃ vācaṃ pahāya pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti; yā sā vācā nelā kaṇṇasukhā pemanīyā hadayaṅgamā porī bahujanakantā bahujanamanāpā tathārūpiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti.
dn2:44.5.eng: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.

dn2:44.7.pli: Samphappalāpaṃ pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti kālavādī bhūtavādī atthavādī dhammavādī vinayavādī, nidhānavatiṃ vācaṃ bhāsitā hoti kālena sāpadesaṃ pariyantavatiṃ atthasaṃhitaṃ.
dn2:44.7.eng: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.

dn2:45.1.eng: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.

dn2:45.2.eng: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.

dn2:45.3.eng: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .

dn2:45.4.eng: They refrain from attiring and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.

dn2:45.5.eng: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.

dn2:45.6.eng: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,

dn2:45.15.eng: They refrain from running errands and messages;

dn2:45.19.eng: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.

dn2:45.21.eng: The shorter section on ethics is finished.

dn2:46.1.pli: Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhaṃ anuyuttā viharanti.
dn2:46.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in injuring plants and seeds.

dn2:46.2.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—mūlabījaṃ khandhabījaṃ phaḷubījaṃ aggabījaṃ bījabījameva pañcamaṃ, iti evarūpā bījagāmabhūtagāmasamārambhā paṭivirato hoti.
dn2:46.2.eng: These include plants propagated from roots, stems, cuttings, or joints; and those from regular seeds as the fifth. They refrain from such injury to plants and seeds.

dn2:47.1.pli: Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ sannidhikāraparibhogaṃ anuyuttā viharanti.
dn2:47.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in storing up goods for their own use.

dn2:47.2.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—annasannidhiṃ pānasannidhiṃ vatthasannidhiṃ yānasannidhiṃ sayanasannidhiṃ gandhasannidhiṃ āmisasannidhiṃ,
dn2:47.2.eng: This includes such things as food, drink, clothes, vehicles, bedding, fragrance, and things of the flesh.

dn2:47.3.pli: iti vā iti evarūpā sannidhikāraparibhogā paṭivirato hoti.
dn2:47.3.eng: They refrain from storing up such goods.

dn2:48.1.pli: Yathā vā paneke bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā saddhādeyyāni bhojanāni bhuñjitvā te evarūpaṃ visūkadassanaṃ anuyuttā viharanti.
dn2:48.1.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, while enjoying food given in faith, still engage in seeing shows.

dn2:48.2.pli: Seyyathidaṃ—naccaṃ gītaṃ vāditaṃ pekkhaṃ akkhānaṃ pāṇissaraṃ vetāḷaṃ kumbhathūṇaṃ sobhanakaṃ caṇḍālaṃ vaṃsaṃ dhovanaṃ hatthiyuddhaṃ assayuddhaṃ mahiṃsayuddhaṃ usabhayuddhaṃ ajayuddhaṃ meṇḍayuddhaṃ kukkuṭayuddhaṃ vaṭṭakayuddhaṃ daṇḍayuddhaṃ muṭṭhiyuddhaṃ nibbuddhaṃ uyyodhikaṃ balaggaṃ senābyūhaṃ anīkadassanaṃ
